required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Respiratory Muscles and Inspiratory Muscle Training
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Inspiratory Muscle Training on Respiratory Muscle Mechanics and Haemodynamics in Healthy Adults

collaborator.agency: Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council, Canada

brief_summary.textblock:
The effects of inspiratory muscle training (IMT) remain controversial. Many studies have examined the effect IMT has on exercise performance, but any changes to the body that come from IMT have yet to be looked at.
This study will look at how someone breathes can change after IMT. Understanding how IMT changes the body can help us use IMT in different treatments.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Post Intervention - ie. immediately after 5 weeks of inspiratory muscle training
primary_outcome.description: Using a multipair esophageal electrode catheter we will determine any changes to the electric activity of the diaphragm

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Post-intervention - ie. immediately after 5 weeks of inspiratory muscle training
secondary_outcome.description: Using surface electromyography to determine the activation patterns of accessory respiratory muscles (scalene and sternocleidomastoid)

other_outcome.time_frame: Post-intervention - ie. immediately after 5 weeks of inspiratory muscle training
other_outcome.description: Using the modified Borg scale to assess changes in perceived dyspnoea after inspiratory muscle training.

other_outcome.time_frame: Post-intervention - ie. immediately after 5 weeks of inspiratory muscle training
other_outcome.description: Using near-infrared spectroscopy to examine if there are any relative changes in concentration (âˆ†umol/Litre) of oxygenated hemoglobin, deoxygenated hemoglobin, and total hemoglobin after training

arm_group.description: Inspiratory muscle training at a low intensity meant to elicit no physiological changes.

intervention.description: A sham training procedure that is meant to elicit no physiologic changes

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Recreationally active, 'Moderate' or 'High' category on International Physical Activity Questionnaire Short form questionnaire
- Able to read and understand English
- Pulmonary function within normal limits
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of or currently smoking
- History or current symptoms of cardiopulmonary disease (including asthma and exercise induced asthma)
- Currently participating and training in a sport at a provincial, national, or international level
- Ulcer or tumor in the esophagus, a nasal septum deviation, or recent nasopharyngeal surgery
- Allergies to latex or local anesthetic
- Contraindications to exercise testing

overall_official.affiliation: University of British Columbia/Centre for Heart Lung Innovation
